rev.diff:
Line 17: Line 17:
The name "Google" is a reference to the word "[[Googol]]", which was coined by [[Milton Sirotta]], nine-year-old nephew of [[United States|U.S.]] [[mathematician]] [[Edward Kasner]] in 1938, to refer to the number represented by 1 followed by one hundred zeros. Google's use of the term reflects the company's mission, which is, "to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful." As a further play on this, Google's headquarters are referred to as, "the Googleplex" (a [[googolplex]] is a 1 followed by a googol of zeros, and the ''-plex'' refers to a [[complex]] of buildings, such as [[multiplex]], cineplex, etc).
The name "Google" is a reference to the word "[[Googol]]", which was coined by [[Milton Sirotta]], nine-year-old nephew of [[United States|U.S.]] [[mathematician]] [[Edward Kasner]] in 1938, to refer to the number represented by 1 followed by one hundred zeros. Google's use of the term reflects the company's mission, which is, "to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful." As a further play on this, Google's headquarters are referred to as, "the Googleplex" (a [[googolplex]] is a 1 followed by a googol of zeros, and the ''-plex'' refers to a [[complex]] of buildings, such as [[multiplex]], cineplex, etc).
â
Google's services are run on several [[server farm]]s, each consisting of many thousand low-cost commodity computers running customized versions of [[Linux]]. While the company does not provide detailed information about its hardware, it was estimated in 2005 that they were using over 100,000 Linux machines. See [[Google platform]] for the details.
+
Google's services are run on several [[server farm]]s, each consisting of many thousand low-cost commodity computers running customized versions of [[Linux]]. While the company does not provide detailed information about its hardware, it was estimated in [[2005]] that they were using over 100,000 Linux machines. See [[Google platform]] for more details on their technology.
